choices.text: Biophysical profile
Doppler
Non-Stress Test
Ultrasound

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida at 36 weeks complained of decreased fetal movements since 1 day. The following test was ordered. What is this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Non-Stress Test

 

  • This is an image of a cardiotocograph, and this test is known as a non-stress test (NST)
  • In an NST, a continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate along with fetal movements is recorded
  • During fetal movements, the fetal heart rate increases (Acceleration)
  • A reactive NST:
    • Baseline heart rate of 110-160 bpm
    •  2 or more accelerations of > 15 bpm in 20 mins
    • Good variability
    • No decelerations

 

Other options:

 

  • Option A: Biophysical profile consists of 5 parameters: Nonstress test, Fetal breathing movements, Fetal movement, Fetal tone and Amniotic fluid index (seen on ultrasound).
  • Option B: An Umbilical Artery Doppler waveform is used to assess vascular resistance. In a normal pregnancy, there is good diastolic flow and the S/D Ratio, Pulsatility Index and Resistance Index (RI) reduce as the pregnancy normally advances.
  • Option D: Ultrasound: This is used in the Biophysical profile where 4 parameters (out of 5) are seen on the ultrasound

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In an NST, a continuous electronic monitoring of the fetal heart rate along with fetal movements is recorded
  • During fetal movements, the fetal heart rate increases (Acceleration)
  • A reactive NST:
    • Baseline heart rate of 110-160 bpm
    •  2 or more accelerations of > 15 bpm in 20 mins
    • Good variability
    • No decelerations

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Amniotic Fluid measurement
Fetal tone
Fetal breathing
Umbilical Artery Doppler

questions.text: A 22-year G2P1 with a history of a previous term still birth at term is now 37 weeks. She complains of decreased fetal movements of 2 days. A Biophysical profile is ordered. All are components of the Biophysical profile except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Umbilical Artery Doppler

 

  • The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:
    • Nonstress test
    • Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
    • Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
    • Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
    • Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”.
    • A score of 8 or 10: Normal
    • A score of 6: Equivocal
    • A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal
    • The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:
    • Nonstress test
    • Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
    • Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
    • Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
    • Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 338

choices.text: Amniotic fluid volume
Fetal movement
Fetal tone
Fetal breathing movement

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida with preeclampsia is undergoing a Biophysical profile. The image shows which component of this test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Amniotic fluid volume

 

Explanation

 

The image is showing the measurement of amniotic fluid volume

 

Other Options:

 

  • Fetal movement
  • Fetal tone
  • Fetal breathing movement

 

All these options are components of the biophysical profile and are seen on real time ultrasound

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:
    • Nonstress test
    • Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
    • Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
    • Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
    • Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).

 

*This image shows the measurement of amniotic fluid being taken (single vertical pocket)

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 338

choices.text: 90 – 110 bpm
100 – 150 bpm
110 – 160 bpm
130 – 180 bpm

questions.text: An intern is on rounds in the antenatal ward. He has been asked to check the fetal heart rate of all the term antenatal patients. What is the normal fetal heart rate at term?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 110 – 160 bpm

 

  • The normal fetal heart rate at term is 110-160 bpm
  • Fetal bradycardia: Fetal heart rate < 110 bpm. Causes
    • Fetal hypoxia as in cord prolapse, abruptio, uteroplacental insufficiency etc
    • Maternal hypotension
    • Prolonged umbilical cord compression
    • Fetal arrythmias
  • Fetal tachycardia. Fetal heart rate > 160 bpm. Causes:
    • Maternal hyperthermia
    • Maternal dehydration
    • Maternal or fetal anemia
    • Maternal Hyperthyroidism
    • Fetal hypoxia
    • Chorioamnionitis
    • Preterm
    • Beta sympathomimetic drugs
    • Fetal arrythmia

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The normal fetal heart rate at term is 110-160 bpm

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Fetal movement count
Modified Biophysical Profile
Non stress test
Umbilical artery Doppler

questions.text: A 25-year G2P1 with twin pregnancy has been diagnosed with Gestational Diabetes Mellitus. She is now 32 weeks. All are methods of antepartum fetal surveillance in her except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Fetal movement count

 

  • Fetal movement count is not a reliable method of fetal surveillance in twin pregnancies
  • Maternal perception of fetal movements may be reduced with
    • Fetal sleep
    • Fetal CNS anomalies
    • Anterior placenta
    • Obesity
    • Chronic smoking
    • Hypoxia

 

Other options:

 

  • Modified BPP refers to NST and AFI.
  • NST is a cardiotocography performed when the patient is not in labour.
  • An Umbilical Artery Doppler waveform is used to assess vascular resistance. In a normal pregnancy, there is good diastolic flow and the S/D Ratio, Pulsatility Index and Resistance Index (RI) reduce as the pregnancy normally advances.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Fetal movement count is not a reliable method of fetal surveillance in twin pregnancies
  • Maternal perception of fetal movements may be reduced with
    • Fetal sleep
    • Fetal CNS anomalies
    • Anterior placenta
    • Obesity
    • Chronic smoking
    • Hypoxia

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: AFI + Umbilical artery doppler
NST + Fetal movements
AFI + NST
NST + Umbilical artery doppler

questions.text: Modified biophysical profile is?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. AFI + NST

 

  • Modified biophysical profile (BPP) consists of a Non-Stress Test (NST) and Ultrasound determination of amniotic fluid volume (Amniotic fluid index - AFI).
  • Modified BPP is considered abnormal when the NST is non-reactive and/ or the AFI < 5.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Modified biophysical profile (BPP) consists of a Non-Stress Test (NST) and Ultrasound determination of amniotic fluid volume (Amniotic fluid index - AFI).

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Biophysical profile
Daily fetal movement count
Non stress test
Ultrasound for biometry

questions.text: A 24-year primi presents at 36 weeks. On examination, the uterus corresponds to 32 weeks, the symphysio-fundal height is 31 cm, the fetus is in cephalic presentation and the fetal heart rate is 140 bpm. Which of the following is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ultrasound for biometry

 

  • The uterine height is less than the period of gestation. Causes could be the following:
    • Fetal growth restriction
    • Oligohydramnios
    • Intra uterine fetal death
    • Wrong dates
    • Transverse lie
  • In this scenario, fetal growth restriction needs to be looked for. The best way to diagnose this is by doing an ultrasound for fetal biometry.
  • Thus, the next best step is ultrasound for biometry option D

 

Other Options:

 

  • Biophysical profile
  • Daily fetal movement count
  • Non stress test

 

These are all tests of antepartum fetal surveillance

 

Educational Objective:

 

Causes of the uterine height less than the period of gestation:

 

  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Intra uterine fetal death
  • Wrong dates
  • Transverse lie

 

Ref: Page no 852, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Call her after 1 week
Emergency LSCS
Immediate induction of labor
Ultrasound for AFI

questions.text: A 24-year G2P1 presents at 37 weeks. A Non -Stress Test is done. The following trace is seen. What is the next best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Call her after 1 week

 

  • This is a reactive NST as
    • The baseline FHR is normal
    • Beat to beat variability is normal (> 5 bpm)
    • There are > 2 accelerations in a 20-minute trace
    • There are no decelerations
  • Hence the patient can be called after 1 week.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Emergency LSCS: As this is a reactive NST, there is no evidence of fetal distress and an emergency delivery is not indicated
  • Immediate induction of labor: As this is a reactive NST and the patient is only 37 weeks, there is no indication for induction of labor
  • Ultrasound for AFI: As the NST is normal, this is not indicated unless there is a suspicion of chronic fetal hypoxia or clinically the liquor appears less.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features of a reactive NST are

 

  • The baseline FHR is normal (110-160 bpm)
  • Beat to beat variability is normal (5 - 25 bpm)
  • There are > 2 accelerations in a 20-minute trace
  • There are no decelerations

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: Absent diastolic flow
Normal diastolic flow
Reduced diastolic flow
Reversal of diastolic flow

questions.text: A 26-year lady with mild pre-eclampsia presents at 32 weeks. On abdominal examination, the uterus corresponds to 28 weeks. Fetal heart rate is 132 bpm. An ultrasound is advised. The following image shows an umbilical artery Doppler. What is your interpretation?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Absent diastolic flow

 

  • The artery seen is the Umbilical Artery
  • An Umbilical Artery Doppler waveform is used to assess vascular resistance
  • In a normal pregnancy, there is good diastolic flow and the S/D Ratio, Pulsatility Index and Resistance Index (RI) reduce as the pregnancy advances
  • The image shows Absent Umbilical Artery Flow which is seen in fetal growth restriction and is an indicator for termination of pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref: Page no 854, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The heart rate of a fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily decelerate with fetal movement.
Heart rate reactivity is believed to be a good indicator of normal fetal autonomic function
Loss of reactivity can be associated with any form of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis.
The nonstress test of the neurologically healthy preterm fetus is frequently non-reactive in up to 50% of tests from 24 to 28 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding the Non-Stress Test?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The heart rate of a fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily decelerate with fetal movement.

 

Let us discuss all the options

 

  • Option A: In the nonstress test, the heart rate of the fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily accelerate with fetal movement.
  • Option B: Heart rate reactivity is believed to be a good indicator of normal fetal autonomic function.
  • Option C: Loss of reactivity may result from any cause of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis. Fetal sleep cycle can also lead to loss of reactivity
  • Option D: The nonstress test of the neurologically healthy preterm fetus is frequently nonreactive—from 24 to 28 weeks of gestation, up to 50 percent of nonstress tests may not be reactive, and from 28 to 32 weeks of gestation, 15 percent of nonstress tests are not reactive.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the nonstress test, the heart rate of the fetus that is not acidotic or neurologically depressed will temporarily accelerate with fetal movement

 

Ref: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 465

choices.text: One or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes
Two or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes
Three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes
Four or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

questions.text: In the biophysical profile, one of the components is fetal movement. This is defined as:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

 

In the Biophysical profile, the definition of a fetal movement is three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes

 

Educational Objective:

 

The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:

 

  • Nonstress test
  • Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
  • Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
  • Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
  • Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”.
    • A score of 8 or 10: Normal
    • A score of 6: Equivocal
    • A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal
    • The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score

 

 Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 338

choices.text: The umbilical artery carries deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta
Flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery of fetuses with normal growth differ from those of fetuses with growth restriction.
The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has a low-velocity diastolic flow.
With extreme intrauterine growth restriction, the diastolic flow may be absent or even reversed

questions.text: All are true regarding umbilical artery Doppler as a modality of antepartum fetal surveillance except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has a low-velocity diastolic flow

 

Let’s discuss all the options

 

  • Option A: The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.
  • Option B: Umbilical artery Doppler flow velocimetry is used as a fetal surveillance technique because flow velocity waveforms in the umbilical artery of fetuses with normal growth differ from those of fetuses with growth restriction.
  • Option C: The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has high-velocity diastolic flow, while in cases of intrauterine growth restriction, the umbilical artery diastolic flow is diminished.
  • Option D: With extreme intrauterine growth restriction, the flow may be absent or even reversed.  There is a high perinatal mortality rate among such pregnancies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The umbilical flow velocity waveform of a normally growing fetus has high-velocity diastolic flow, while in cases of intrauterine growth restriction, the umbilical artery diastolic flow is diminished

 

Ref: Williams textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg  213

choices.text: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor
Emergency LSCS
Repeat NST after hydration, Oxygen and left lateral position
Repeat Biophysical profile after hydration, oxygen and left lateral position

questions.text: A 26-year G2P1 with a previous LSCS presents at 35 weeks with fetal growth restriction. She complains of decreased fetal movements for 1 day. A biophysical profile is ordered, and the Manning score is 2. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Emergency LSCS

 

A Manning sore of 2 indicates fetal hypoxia and hence immediate delivery should be done. A hypoxic fetus may not tolerate the stress of labor and hence an emergency LSCS is the best way to deliver this fetus

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A: Corticosteroids followed by induction of labor: Not indicated as she is > 34 weeks
  • Option B: Repeat NST after hydration, Oxygen and left lateral position: This is unlikely to help with a Manning score of 2
  • Option C: Repeat Biophysical profile after hydration, oxygen and left lateral position: This is unlikely to help improve the Manning score in an already hypoxic fetus

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The five components of the biophysical profile are as follows:
  • Nonstress test
  • Fetal breathing movements (one or more episodes of rhythmic fetal breathing movements of 30 seconds or more within 30 minutes)
  • Fetal movement (three or more discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes)
  • Fetal tone (one or more episodes of extension of a fetal extremity with return to flexion, or opening or closing of a hand; and
  • Determination of the amniotic fluid volume (a single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid exceeding 2 cm is considered evidence of adequate amniotic fluid).
  • Each of the components is given a score of 2 (normal or present as defined previously) or 0 (abnormal, absent, or insufficient). This score is called “Manning Score”.
    • A score of 8 or 10: Normal
    • A score of 6: Equivocal
    • A score of ≤ 4: Abnormal
    • The presence of oligohydramnios should warrant further evaluation regardless of the composite score

 

Ref: William’s textbook of Obstetrics 25th edition pg 338

choices.text: Extend the trace for another 20 minutes
Immediate cesarean section
Induction of labor
Reassure the patient and call her after 1 week

questions.text: A 24-year primigravida presents to the OPD at 37 weeks complaining of decreased fetal movement. An NST is taken which shows the following. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Extend the trace for another 20 minutes

 

  • This is a non-reassuring trace as
    • There are no accelerations
    • There is reduced baseline variability
  • Loss of reactivity may result from fetal sleep cycle or any cause of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis.
  • If the NST is non reassuring, it should be continued for a further 20 minutes or a Vibro-acoustic stimulation is done to reduce the fetal sleep state from quiet (non-REM) to active (REM) sleep.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Loss of reactivity may result from fetal sleep cycle or any cause of central nervous system depression, including fetal acidosis.
  • If the NST is non reassuring, it should be continued for a further 20 minutes or a Vibro-acoustic stimulation is done to reduce the fetal sleep state from quiet (non-REM) to active (REM) sleep.

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition

choices.text: 2 cm
4 cm
5 cm
8 cm

questions.text: Oligohydramnios is defined as a single deepest pocket less than?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 2 cm

 

Oligohydramnios is defined as an AFI < 5cm or a SVP < 2cm

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amniotic Fluid can be measured by

 

  1. Amniotic Fluid Index
  2. Single deepest pocket

 

Single Deepest Pocket

 

  • Or Maximal vertical pocket
  • The ultrasound probe is held perpendicular to the floor and parallel to the long axis of the woman. 
  • The largest vertical pocket of fluid is identified and measured.
  • Unit of measurement: cm/ mm
  • The single deepest pocket of liquor is considered normal if between 2 - 8 cm
  • More useful in 2nd trimester assessment of amniotic fluid and in multiple gestation. 

 

Ref: Page no 227, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 20 weeks
24 weeks
28 weeks
32 weeks

questions.text: An intern is taking rounds in the antenatal ward. He has been asked to auscultate the fetal hearts of all pregnant patients. Above which gestational age, will he be able to hear the FHR by a stethoscope?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20 weeks

 

  • The fetal heart can be auscultated by the bell of a stethoscope by 20 weeks gestation
  • The fetal heart can be auscultated with a handheld Doppler after 14 weeks of gestation

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The fetal heart can be auscultated by the bell of a stethoscope by 20 weeks gestation
  • The fetal heart can be auscultated with a handheld Doppler after 14 weeks of gestation

 

Ref: Page no 98, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition
